title: Erdős Problem #1011: Triangles in Graphs with High Chromatic Number
description: Let f_r(n) be minimal such that every n-vertex graph with ≥ f_r(n) edges and χ ≥ r contains a triangle. Known: f_2(n) = ⌊n²/4⌋+1 (Turán), f_3(n) = ⌊(n-1)²/4⌋+2 (Erdős-Gallai). Asymptotic involves g(r) ~ r² log r. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: This problem connects three fundamental graph invariants: edge count, chromatic number, and triangle existence. Turán's theorem (1941) completely solved the case r=2. Erdős and Gallai (1962) determined f_3(n). Simonovits's PhD thesis established the asymptotic form involving g(r). Recent work by Davies-Illingworth (2022) and Hefty-Horn-King-Pfender (2025) narrowed the bounds on g(r) to within a factor of 4.
overview.problemStatement: Let f_r(n) be minimal such that every graph on n vertices with at least f_r(n) edges and chromatic number at least r contains a triangle. Determine f_r(n).
overview.proofStrategy: The Lean formalization defines f_r(n) as a threshold function on graphs with chromatic number constraints. Known exact values for r=2,3,4 are stated as axioms. The Simonovits asymptotic f_r(n) = n²/4 - g(r)n/2 + O(1) introduces the key quantity g(r). Bounds on g(r) capture current knowledge: (1/2)r² log r ≤ g(r) ≤ 2r² log r.
keyInsights: Simonovits asymptotic: f_r(n) = n²/4 - g(r)n/2 + O(1)
g(r) = max vertices to remove from χ≥r triangle-free graph to make bipartite
Bounds: (1/2-o(1))r² log r ≤ g(r) ≤ (2+o(1))r² log r

conclusion.summary: The threshold f_r(n) for forcing triangles in graphs with chromatic number ≥ r is well-understood for small r but the general asymptotic remains open. Simonovits showed f_r(n) = n²/4 - g(r)n/2 + O(1) where g(r) captures how far triangle-free χ≥r graphs are from bipartite. Current bounds show g(r) ~ r² log r with a factor-of-4 gap in the constant.
conclusion.implications: This connects extremal graph theory (Turán-type problems) with chromatic theory. Understanding g(r) would reveal how chromatic number constrains triangle-free graphs. The recent progress on R(3,k) (the Ramsey number) directly impacts the upper bound on g(r).
openQuestions: What is the exact constant c such that g(r) ~ c·r² log r?
What is f_5(n)? Higher exact values unknown.
Can Simonovits's O(1) error be made explicit?
